title-group.article-title: Pollutant dispersion in a natural ventilated dental clinic

abstract.p: Mechanical ventilation poses some challenges for control of pollutants in a fully enclosed dental clinic. Natural ventilation is used in some clinics because of its high exhausting efficiency and low non-renewable energy consumption. In this study, a dental clinic model was built using a computational fluid dynamics platform. The objective was to study the effect of natural ventilation on pollutant dispersion in this setting. The evaluations were conducted using the advanced turbulence model, large eddy simulation for the flow field and the discrete phase modelling for pollutant tracks. Three basic ventilation paths were identified, the ‘single narrow path’, ‘narrow path’ and ‘dispersive path’. The results show that the first of these had the highest efficiency, with an escape time of about 1/30 and 1/100 of the narrow and dispersive paths, respectively. Despite the position of the pollutant source and facilities such as bulkheads, escape time was significantly reduced when the ventilation flow rate was increased under the single narrow and dispersive paths. However, for the narrow path, these factors played a more dominant role in the escape time than the ventilation flow rate.
Practical application: This study is expected to provide information and guidance in understanding the pollutant spread in a naturally ventilated room such as a dental clinic.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In hospitals and health care facilities, increasing interest has been focused on indoor air quality because of the mixture of pollutants that may be present. These include chemical compounds, microorganisms and biological infectious agents. Such pollutants are dangerous to the health of both patients and health care providers because of their indoor dispersion.

Some attempts have been made to assess the indoor air quality of ventilated dental clinics. Pankhurst and Coulter review the evidence that dental unit waterlines are a source of occupational and health care-acquired infection in dental surgeries.1 A microbiological environmental investigation was carried out in six clinics.2 The microbial water, air and surface contaminations were studied before and during working hours, and also at the end of the daily treatment. The microbial environmental contamination of different test time varies widely from each other. The larger collections of data were suggested as the basic of the microbial environmental contamination researches. Environmental pollution before and after dental procedures is also evaluated by Cellini.3 The results show that the use of effective control procedures, and in particular an air-filtration system, can be helpful in reducing airborne environmental contamination. Furthermore, Smith and colleagues4 study the room layout and ventilation performance for pollutant concentration using primary data collected using a survey methodology.

Pollutant dispersion is primarily influenced by ventilation performance. This has been investigated under various risk conditions. The results of both measurement and simulation studies show that ventilation can improve indoor air quality.5–7 Some research focuses on the optimal configuration or review of the ventilation system. The work of Santamouris and colleagues shows that the concentrations of CO2 decrease with enhanced airflow rates.8 In a review of different air-conditioning systems9 for indoor air quality control, the use of the dedicated outdoor air system (DOAS) and independent control of temperature and humidity system (ICTHS) are proposed in order to eliminate microbial pollution. However, there have been fewer investigations of the pollutant distribution caused by the complex natural ventilation method.

Natural ventilation is often proposed in health care settings in order to control infection. It has a higher efficiency and lower energy consumption compared with mechanical ventilation systems. Furthermore, building-related illness (BRI), sick building syndrome (SBS) and Legionnaires’ disease are all typically caused by air-conditioning systems. Seppanen and Fisk10 show that the prevalence of SBS in buildings using air-conditioning systems is between 30 and 200% higher than those which employ natural ventilation. Deaths caused by Legionnaires’ disease have even occurred in direct evaporative cooling systems.11 Furthermore, the outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) took place in 2003.12,13 These indoor environment problems relating to the use of air-conditioning systems have all taken place in buildings which use them for ventilation. In order to avoid such problems, reduce energy consumption and improve ventilation efficiency, the use of natural ventilation in residential buildings has been promoted by the Hong Kong Government. As a sustainable method, it could also be used in dental clinics in Hong Kong due to their air intake status.

In Hong Kong, in 2010, there were 1935 registered dentists, according to The Dental Council of Hong Kong, and about 900 clinics. A sample of 795 dental clinics was chosen in order to observe the common environmental conditions and the ventilation systems in use. Details are shown in Figures 1–4. From Figure 1, it can be seen that 47% of the dental clinics were located in commercial buildings. Furthermore, 86% of the ventilation methods used in these buildings were central air-conditioning systems. Others also in use were window-mounted and split-air type air conditioners. In terms of location, 18% of the dental clinics were in shopping malls, 90% of which used central air-conditioning systems. Window-mounted or split-air type systems were always used in those clinics located in private houses (15%), public housing (5%) and tenements (15%). The percentage of clinics using central air-conditioning systems was 59% and using other types was 41% (Figure 2). As Figure 4 shows, the percentage with a fresh air intake at roadside was 93%. In naturally ventilated buildings, pollutant control is always decided by ventilation performance. Karava and colleagues14 examine the airflow of cross-ventilation in a single-zone building using a wind tunnel experiment. The results show that it is difficult to predict the airflow pattern using an experimental method. Furthermore, the parameters, including inlet-to-outlet ratio and the positions of the openings in the façade wall, should be considered in the design of natural ventilation. Qian and colleagues15 report on a field measurement exercise in a hospital. They conclude that when all doors and windows are open, a high ventilation rate can be achieved. Such previous work demonstrates the high efficiency of natural ventilation and the importance of having sufficient openings in reducing the level of pollution caused by hazardous substances. Generally, however, this can be influenced much more significantly by the ventilation operation schemes16,17 used in a naturally ventilated room.

Accordingly, the objective of this study was to study the effect of natural ventilation on pollutant dispersion in a dental clinic. The computational fluid dynamics (CFD) method was applied. The more accurate turbulence model, large eddy simulation (LES) was used to study the flow field after validation with open experimental data. Discrete phase modelling (DPM) was then applied to study the pollutant dispersion. A simulation was conducted to study the ventilation paths and pollutant dispersion of various ventilation flow rates.

sec.title: Methodology
sec.p: CFD is a commonly used method of studying the natural ventilation performance and the particle dispersion outside and inside a building.18–20 The accuracy of the simulation is largely decided by the choice of the turbulence model and meshing case.

sec.title: Airflow modelling using LES
sec.p: In the LES model, turbulent flows are characterized by eddies with a wide range of length and timescale. The largest eddies are typically comparable in size to the characteristic length of the mean flow. The smallest are responsible for the dissipation of turbulent kinetic energy. For all flows, CFD code FLUENT solves the conservation equations for mass, momentum and energy. In LES, the three conservation equations can be solved directly in large eddies, while the smaller eddies are modelled. Large eddies are dictated by the geometry and boundary conditions of the problem to be resolved. Small eddies are less dependent on geometry, tend to be more isotropic and are consequently more universal.

The renormalization-group (RNG) k-epsilon model is derived using RNG theory. It is similar in form to the standard k-epsilon model, but with some refinements, such as an additional term in the epsilon equation for the calculation accuracy of rapidly strained flows, enhanced accuracy for swirling flows and the use of an analytical formula for the turbulent Prandtl number rather than the constant values found in the standard k-epsilon model. There is also an effective viscosity that accounts for low-Reynolds-number effects.

A coarser mesh can be used to resolve only the large eddies in LES compared with direct numerical simulation (DNS); however, LES still requires much finer meshes than those for the RNG k-epsilon model calculations. In addition, LES has to be run for a sufficiently long flow-time in order to obtain stable statistics of the flow being modelled. To sum up, the computational cost of LES is normally higher than that of the steady RNG k-epsilon model. Therefore, high-performance computing (such as parallel computing) is a necessity for using LES, especially in industrial applications.

The governing equations for LES are obtained by filtering the time-dependent Navier-Stokes equations in either Fourier (wave number) or configuration (physical) space. The filtering process effectively filters out those eddies whose scales are smaller than the filter width or grid spacing used in the computations. The resulting equations thus govern the dynamics of large eddies.

sec.title: Discrete phase modelling
sec.p: There are two approaches to studying the indoor particles dispersed in the continuous phase, namely the Euler-Lagrange and the Euler-Euler methods. Generally, when the discrete phase is present at a fairly low volume fraction, that is, less than 10–12%, the case of particle dispersion in the indoor air should be simulated by the Lagrangian discrete phase model. In FLUENT, this follows the Euler-Lagrange approach. The fluid phase is treated as a continuum by solving the time-averaged Navier-Stokes equations, while the dispersed phase is solved by tracking a large number of particles through the calculated flow field.

The trajectory of the particle in the second phase can be predicted by integrating the force balance on the particle in FLUENT, and the dispersion of particles due to turbulence in the fluid phase can be predicted using the stochastic tracking model. The integration of the force on the particle is described as equation (8) (8)dupdt=FD(u-up)+gx(ρp-ρ)ρp+Fx where

ρ = the fluid density,

sec.title: Ventilation paths in a two-dimensional simulation
sec.p:
The dental clinic model used in the CFD simulation was based on the study of Stathopoulou and colleagues.16 There were six windows on one wall, and three doors on the opposite wall. In this clinic, the dental chairs were also spaced using the partition walls as shown in Figure 5. Two staff rooms were placed on one side. Figure 5.
The layout of the dental clinic.

In order to investigate the typical ventilation paths, the dental clinic was simplified into a two-dimensional (2D) model as shown in Figure 6. The door opening and the window opening width are all 900 mm. Facilities such as bulkheads and staff rooms were ignored. The model was simplified into a chamber with three doors and six windows on opposite sides. The computational domain and meshing case of this 2D model are shown in Figure 6. The velocity inlet of the computational domain was set as 5 times, and the pressure outlet 10 times, the room width. The two sides were also set as five times of the room width away from the room side. The total number of elements was 432,000 with the worst element having an EquiSize Skew of 0.56. This is much less than the computable number (0.9). The grid numbers of the openings were all 20, because more detailed and accurate flow field around the openings was required. Figure 6.
(a) The simplified two-dimensional (2D) simulation model and (b) computational domain.

When the inlet/inlets of the room flow field were chosen from the three doors and the outlet/outlets from the six windows, several combinations of door/doors and window/windows were generated. All of these were simulated, as listed in Table 1. The different types of ventilation paths were induced from the 57 combinations of opened doors and windows inside the clinic. Table 1.

sec.title: Three types of ventilation paths
sec.p:
Three basic types of ventilation paths were obtained from the results of all the combination cases according to the dispersion conditions. Examples are shown in Figure 7. Figure 7.
Examples of three types of natural ventilation paths: (a) type 1: single-narrow path; (b) type 2: narrow path and (c) type 3: dispersion path.

Type 1 was summed up using 7 cases from the total of 57. It can be called the ‘single narrow path’, and its route is basically the same as the distance from the inlet to the outlet. In the dental clinic setting, the dispersive area of type 1 was the smallest, so it had the minimum spread potential. Pollution from hazardous substances can be avoided as long as the patients and the dental staff do not remain in the same ventilation route.

Type 2 can be called the ‘narrow path’. It was summed using 5 of the 57 cases, but includes several ventilation routes. In this type, the number of ventilation paths equals the larger value between the inlets and outlets. The dispersive area is almost the smallest but is still larger than type 1. Generally, in this situation, it will be easy to remain clear of pollution from hazardous substances so long as the particle tracks can be avoided.

Type 3 is the ‘dispersive path’ summed up from 45 of the 57 total cases. In practice, this type is common but easily enables cross-contamination. This condition always occurs when the outlet across is displaced further away on the opposite wall or when the wind coming from different inlets mixes together. The natural wind passes through almost the whole room. In this situation, the pollutants (especially those where deposition was difficult) were carried by the wind. The escape time of the pollutants from the office was much longer than those of the other types, and their spread area was also larger.

sec.title: Validation of CFD method
sec.p:
In this study, the validation was conducted using the experimental data from the published work of Chen and colleagues,21 who investigated the flow field in a room model. The chamber was as shown in Figure 8, and its geometric size was 0.8 m (length) × 0.4 m (width) × 0.4 m (height). The simple room model used in the experimental test could avoid the complex factors which influenced the flow field. Although CFD has the same advantages as wind tunnel tests,22 the possible improvement of the investigation by using a numerical simulation could be limited by computing capabilities. The accuracy of the numerical method must be enhanced according to the requirements of the real flow-field analysis. Validation against the experiment was required to find a better solution method for the simulation. In the room model shown in Figure 8, the inlet and outlet of the room model both had the same size, 0.04 m × 0.04 m, and their positions were symmetrical with the plane y = 0.2 m. Figure 8.
Schematic of the ventilation chamber.

In the CFD simulation, structured grids were used in the mesh solution, so it was of very good quality and the worst EquiSize Skew was 1.3e–10. The number of total elements was 858,000. The refined elements were applied along the walls of the chamber. The turbulent models used here in the numerical method were the RNG k-epsilon and LES. In order to employ the LES turbulence model, the non-dimensional parameter y+ was used to examine the near-wall regions, defined in equation (13). From the results of the standard k-epsilon model and LES model, the values of y+ were smaller than 5.3, and the maximum y+ appeared near the outlet opening. So (13)y+=ρuτypu where
uτ=τw/ρw = the friction velocity,
yP = the distance from a point P near the wall to the wall,
ρ = the fluid density and
μ = the fluid viscosity at point P.

Figure 8 shows the comparison of the measured and predicted velocities at three different locations. Figure 9 indicates that the LES model has a better agreement with the experiments in the near-wall regions than does the RNG k-epsilon model. Generally, the RNG model overestimates, and the LES underestimates, the velocity magnitude. From the results of the RNG model, the velocities near the walls in the level of the inlet opening were much larger than the experimental data, although the grids were refined. These RNG results were seriously flawed in the areas where there were relatively dramatic changes in velocity. Figure 9.
Comparisons of the measured and predicted velocities at three different locations: (a) x = 0.2 m; (b) x = 0.4 m and (c) x = 0.6 m.

sec.title: Simulation model of a dental clinic
sec.p:
In the three-dimensional (3D) model, the door opening size is 900 mm (width) × 2000 mm (height), and the window opening size is 800 mm (width) × 1000 mm (height). Three cases related to different ventilation path types were studied in this work, each including two different positions for the particle source. Source 1 was set to be a stable position on the dental chair in the clinic near window outlet opening W-4, and Source 2 was near the door inlet opening D-2. The positions of the particle sources are shown in Figure 10. The source position was assumed on the dental chair surface as a patient lying on the chair. The material of particle source is assumed as Ca10(PO4)6(OH)2, with the diameter 0.01 mm. The density of the pollutant source is 3160 kg/m3. The particle is exhausted at 0.02 m/s normal to the ceiling of the clinic. Figure 10.
The two positions of the particle sources in the dental clinic.

sec.title: Numerical case descriptions and iteration control
sec.p: In the dental clinic model, the total number of elements was 800,000, and the worst EquiSize Skew 0.388. The grids were almost of the structured type, except for the narrow aisle. The focused results were the general flow field and the particle tracks, so the refined elements were not used in the near-wall region.

The dental chairs were set to be solid, and the partitions set to be walls in order to block the wind. The two staff rooms were also treated as solid, because the closed doors prevented wind from entering them. Experimental data, that is, velocities, from the dental clinic research of Stathopoulou and his colleagues16 were used as the boundary conditions in the numerical simulation. The initial velocity inlet was set to be 1 m/s, which could be calculated from the flow rate of 1.8 m3/s. The pollutant sources were set as described above. The inlet velocities were then changed to 2 m/s and 3 m/s in the three cases to study the particle escape time.

A LES model was used to study the turbulent flow field. One of the three doors was defined as the velocity inlet and a number of the six windows defined as pressure outlets. Residuals were set to be lower than 10–4. The pressure implicit with splitting of operators (PISO) program was used to solve the pressure–velocity coupling. The spatial discretization schemes were least squares cell based for gradient, PRESTO! for pressure and bounded central differencing for momentum. The second order implicit was used for transient formulation.

sec.title: Ventilation performance
sec.p:
Figure 11 shows the velocity contours of the plane at the height of 1.2 m. D-2 and W-3 were chosen as the inlet and outlet openings in Figure 11(a), and D-2 and W-6 were selected in Figure 11(b). Other doors and windows were closed. It was assumed that the height of the breath level when people inside the clinic were sitting down was 1.2 m. The maximum velocity appeared near the outlet window because the area of window opening was smaller than that of the door opening, on the basis of mass conservation. There are several contours of the larger velocity in Figure 11(b), because of the partitioned walls and the long distance between the velocity inlet door and outlet window. Figure 11.
Velocity contours at the breath level at the room inlet velocity of 1 m/s. (a) Inlet D-2; Outlet W-3; (b) Inlet D-2; Outlet W-6.

sec.title: Pollutant dispersion of the three cases
sec.p:
Each of three simulation cases, Cases 1, 2 and 3, belonged to ventilation path type 1 (the single-narrow path), type 2 (the narrow path) and type 3 (the dispersive path), respectively. In Case 1, D-2 and W-4 were chosen as the inlet and outlet openings; in Case 2, these were D-2 and W-3 and in case 3, D-2 and W-6 were chosen. In all cases, all the other doors and windows in the dental clinic were closed. In each of these three cases, there were two conditions with different source positions (Sources 1 and 2). Source 1 was placed at the dental chair near D-2 and Source 2 at the chair near W-4. Figure 12 shows the particle tracks in the clinic. Figure 12(a) and (b) is totally different due to the blockage caused by facilities such as bulkheads. In Figure 12(a) for Case 1, the escape time of one bundle of particles from Source 2 was much less than that of Source 1 because of the shorter escape path. The escape times from Sources 2 and 1 were 9.12 s and 45.4 s, respectively. A longer escape time means that the pollutant particle may have more influence on patients and staff located close to the source. In Figure 12(b) for Case 2, the escape times from Sources 1 and 2 were 190 s and 278 s respectively. It can be seen from Figure 12(c) for Case 3 that the area of pollutant spread from Source 1 was larger than that from Source 2. However, the potential for infection from Source 2 was greater due to the higher concentration of the pollutant, as shown in Figure 12(c). The escape times from Sources 1 and 2 were 856 s and 609 s, respectively. In all three cases with two situations (two source positions), the shortest escape time was only 9.12 s and the longest was 856 s. The longest escape time was therefore almost 100 times the shortest. Figure 12.
The particle tracks of the different positions of particle sources (Sources 1 and 2) for three cases at the room inlet velocity of 1 m/s. (a) Case 1 (D-2 W-4); (b) Case 1 (D-2 W-3); (c) Case 1 (D-2 W-6).

Figure 13 shows the variation of escape time of particles in the dental clinic mapped against room inlet velocity for Cases 1, 2 and 3. These results were obtained using the ‘trap’ wall function.23 It can be seen from Figure 13(a) and (b) that the escape times of particles of different ventilation path types across the three cases were quite different at different room inlet velocities. For example, the escape time for the ventilation path type 1 (single-narrow path) in Case 1 (D-2, W-4) is much less than for the other two cases. Although the ventilation path in Case 2 (D-2, W-3) is type 2 (narrow path), the escape time was almost the largest of the three cases because of the blockage caused by the partition wall near the particle sources. It can be seen that when the particle sources were close to the window, the escape time for Source 2 was less than that for Source 1. Furthermore, the escape time of the particles under the dispersion type of ventilation in Case 3 (D-2, W-6) was greatly reduced by the enhanced inlet velocity, which can therefore be helpful in exhausting the supply of particles. However, the position of the particle source and internal facilities had a more significant effect than ventilation inlet velocity on the escape time for the type 2 ventilation path seen in Case 2. Figure 13.
Escape time of particles in the dental clinic against room inlet velocity for the three cases. (a) The particle source 1 for Case 1 Case 2 and Case 3; (b) The particle source 2 for Case 1 Case 2 and Case 3.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: This study looked at the effect of natural ventilation on pollutant dispersion in a dental clinic. It examined the positions and ventilation path types of the clinic. Pollutant dispersion was analyzed using CFD simulation. The advanced turbulent model LES was used to simulate the flow field and DPM to evaluate the particle dispersion.

It can be concluded that there were three types of ventilation paths, namely the single-narrow, narrow and dispersive types. From the analysis of particle tracks in the Source 1 condition, the escape time of the particles under the single-narrow ventilation type was almost 1/70 of that under the dispersive type and 1/30 of that under the narrow path type. From the analysis of particle tracks in the Source 2 condition, the escape time of the particles under the single-narrow ventilation type was almost 1/5 of that under the dispersive type and 1/20 of that under the narrow path type. The longest escape time was almost 100 times the shortest. The escape time of the particles under both the dispersive and single-narrow ventilation paths could be much reduced by enhancing the ventilation inlet velocity, and under the narrow ventilation path was far more influenced by the positions of the particle source and the clinic facilities.

In conclusion, the dispersive ventilation path should be avoided in a natural, ventilated dental clinic when windows and doors are opened under high-pollutant condition. Under low-pollutant condition, the dispersive ventilation path can used to decrease the indoor air age.
